title: Resource Page Link Building: The Only Guide You Need
description: Resource page link building is a known and popular link building tactic. This guide shows you how to do it right.
content: Joshua Hardwick Head of Content @ Ahrefs (or, in plain English, I'm the guy responsible for ensuring that every blog post we publish is EPIC). Get the week's best marketing content Email Subscription Subscribe Leave this field empty if you're human: Contents Resource page link building is nothing new, but it remains a popular link building tactic.How popular? According to Airaâ€™s 2022 State of Link Building Report, 24% of SEOs use it:Here are three reasons why:It works.Itâ€™s scalable.Itâ€™s relatively easy.In this guide, Iâ€™ll explain how to build links from resource pages in three simple steps. But first, letâ€™s make sure weâ€™re on the same page.ContentsWhat is resource page link building?Resource page link building is where you get backlinks from webpages that curate and link out to useful industry resources.Hereâ€™s what a typical resource page looks like: If you have a great design resource, you can reach out to the creator of that page and suggest it for inclusion. Why does resource page link building work?Suggesting a useful resource to a resource page owner helps keep the page fresh and up to date. Thatâ€™s why many of their creators actually ask for submissions.Example of a resource page owner asking for suggestions.This means you donâ€™t have to do too much convincing to get useful resources added.How to build links from resource pagesYouâ€™ll first need a useful resource to pitch. This can be your homepage. But in most cases, itâ€™ll be an informational resource or interactive tool. If you donâ€™t have that, read our guide to creating link bait. If youâ€™re good to go, follow this process:Find relevant resource pagesVet the pagesReach out and suggest your resource1. Find relevant resource pagesThe easiest way to do this is with Google search operators. To set yourself up for success, start by doing these three things:Create a free Ahrefs Webmaster Tools accountInstall Ahrefsâ€™ SEO ToolbarGo here and set the number of Google search results per page to 100Next, head back to Google and type a broad keyword related to your resource followed by this search operator: intitle:resources inurl:resources.html. For example, if your resource is a keto diet calculator, you may search for this:Next, click the SEO Toolbar icon in your browser and toggle â€œSERP toolsâ€ on, as well as â€œResults metricsâ€ under the SERP settings.You should now see an Ahrefs overlay in the Google search results with an â€œExport CSVâ€ button. Click this to export the results. You can then repeat the process for other similar search operators to find more pages, such as:fitness intitle:resources inurl:links.htmlfitness intitle:links inurl: resources.htmlfitness inurl:.com/resourcesfitness inurl:resources intitle:resourcesSidenote. Make sure to change the keyword to something relevant to your resource. Itâ€™s also best to keep it quite broad, as youâ€™ll struggle to find relevant results if you go too niche.If you want even more search operators, use this Google sheet. All you have to do is add up to 10 keywords in the highlighted cells, then head over to the â€œResultsâ€ tab where youâ€™ll have hundreds of search operators ready to go.Finally, you can merge all the exported CSVs using this website.Time-saving tipIf this process sounds like too much hard work, fill in the Google sheet with your keywords and send them to your virtual assistant along with these instructions: Install Ahrefsâ€™ SEO ToolbarOpen this Google sheet: [insert link]Click the first link â€œSERP linkâ€ in the tab labeled â€œResultsâ€Click the â€œExport CSVâ€ button on the Ahrefs overlay in the search resultsRepeat this for the other operators in the sheetUse this website to merge the CSVs into one Send the final â€œmasterâ€ CSV file to me, and bill for your time ğŸ™‚ Or, if you prefer an automated solution, use a tool like ScrapeBox or Citation Labs Link Prospector. Just keep in mind that neither of these are free. Youâ€™ll need proxies for ScrapeBox, and scrapes in Citation Labs cost $1â€“$5 a pop.2. Vet the pagesNot all of the results you scraped from Google will be relevant, so you need to vet them before reaching out. This is a two-step process: Filter and eliminate using metricsManually review the remaining pagesA. Filter and eliminate using metricsYouâ€™ve probably got far too many pages on your list to realistically vet by hand, but luckily you can weed out most of the junk with SEO metrics. Follow this flowchart to find the easiest way to get these metrics for you:As the flowchart explains, if you have a paid Ahrefs plan and used our SEO Toolbar to extract Googleâ€™s results, the metrics are already in your CSV. If not, there are two options:Bulk check â€“ Enter up to 200 URLs at a time into our Batch Analysis tool, or use a third-party tool like Screaming Frog or URL Profiler that connects to the Ahrefs API. Skip this step â€“ While you could use our free traffic checker and free Domain Rating checker to pull metrics for each URL individually, it would take far too long. Itâ€™s better just to skip this step and vet all pages manually.Once youâ€™ve pulled the metrics, you can just filter the spreadsheet for prospects that match your requirements. If youâ€™re not sure where to start, hereâ€™s my suggestion:Domain Rating (DR) >= 10Domain Search Traffic (ST): >= 5000This should be enough to cut the list down by around 70%.Sidenote. You can also filter the URL column to remove pages from certain websites, like Twitter or Facebook.B. Manually review the remaining pagesThe easiest way to do this is to open the remaining URLs in batches of five to 10 and review the pages manually. You can use openallurls.com to make this easier. This process is a bit subjective, but youâ€™re basically looking for pages that:Link out to external resources.Link to other topically related resources.Look like someone cares about maintaining them.But most importantly, you should look to identify the pages where the addition of your link will add value. Make an effort to do that, and your conversion rate will skyrocket.For any prospects that donâ€™t meet your requirements, put an â€œxâ€ in the URL/target column to signify that you donâ€™t need to pitch them. 3. Reach out and suggest your resourceLastly, you need to find the person responsible for maintaining each resource page and let them know your content exists.That goes something like this:Hey, [Name].Just came across your list of resources here: [link].We just created [x].It might make a worthwhile addition to the page.Sidenote. Iâ€™ve purposely paraphrased this template to encourage you to add your own creative flair.Here are a few tips to get the most from your efforts:Tip 1. Respect their preferred contact methodMail merges are your friend when it comes to doing email outreach at scale. But you shouldnâ€™t ignore the personâ€™s preferred contact method just to make your life easier.If someone says you should submit resources using a contact form, respect their wishes.Tip 2. Email the person responsible for the pageEmailing [email protected] is usually avoidable. Itâ€™s what lazy marketers do when they canâ€™t be bothered to hunt down a real personâ€™s email address.Donâ€™t be that marketer. Make an effort to figure out whoâ€™s responsible for the page and contact them directly. Your conversion rate will thank you for it. Further reading6 Ways to Find Anyoneâ€™s Email Address (Tried & Tested)Tip 3. Tell them where the link should goLinks on resource pages are often divided into subgroups. Donâ€™t hesitate to tell the recipient where you think your resource should be placed. Itâ€™s helpful.Tip 4. Point out broken links on the pageBroken links on a resource page are yet another incentive for the site owner to edit them. And if theyâ€™re doing that, they may as well add your resource while theyâ€™re there. Hereâ€™s an easy (and free) way to check for dead links on a page:Go to â€œOutgoing linksâ€ on Ahrefsâ€™ SEO ToolbarClick â€œCheck statusâ€You can then filter for broken links and export them. Itâ€™s then just a case of letting the site owner know about the dead links in your email.TipIf youâ€™re using Screaming Frog and want to make this process more efficient, just hit Bulk Export > Response codes > External Links > External Client Error (4xx) Inlinks.You can then work some spreadsheet magic (VLOOKUP, QUERY) to pull this data into your master prospecting file. That makes it easy to templatize outreach emails using custom mail-merge fields in popular outreach tools like BuzzStream, Pitchbox, and Mailshake.Tip 5. Donâ€™t payBuying links is against Googleâ€™s guidelines. Plus, if someone is selling links on a resource page, chances are the page will be pretty useless and spammy.How to find even more resource pages with easeFollow all of the instructions above, and it should be enough to land at least a handful of resource page links in most niches. But why stop there? There are plenty of other ways to find even more resource pages.Here are three of them: 1. Search the backlink profiles of sites with known resource page linksGiven that resource page link building is a common link building tactic, if a page has a link from one resource page, it probably has links from other resource pages.Hereâ€™s how to find those resource pages:Crawl your vetted list of resource pages with Screaming FrogGo to Bulk Export > Links > External LinksOpen the CSV and copy all URLs in the â€œDestinationâ€ column Paste them into this Google sheetGo to the â€œResultsâ€ tabYou should now see a list of websites that have at least one resource page backlink:From here, you can simply paste any relevant domains into Ahrefsâ€™ Site Explorer, go to the Backlinks report, and search for â€œresources.htmâ€ in the referring page URL. For example, if we do this for eatright.org, we get 344 results: Hereâ€™s just one example:2. Search for listicle resource pagesMost â€œtraditionalâ€ resource page search operators wonâ€™t find listicles like this:Thatâ€™s a shame because these are also â€œresourceâ€ pages in their own right, as they list and link useful resources.To find these pages, just search Google for â€œbest [thing]â€. For example, if you run a gym in London, you could simply search for â€œbest gyms in londonâ€:You can then use Ahrefsâ€™ SEO Toolbar to extract these to a CSV file (along with SEO metrics, for paying customers).If youâ€™re an Ahrefs user, you can speed up your search using Content Explorer. Just run an â€œIn titleâ€ search and filter for pages that match your criteria (e.g., DR 30+). Or if you prefer, plug a competitor into Site Explorer, go to the Backlinks report, and search for referring pages with â€œbest [thing]â€ in their titles.3. Search for pages with resource sectionsNot all resource pages are pages dedicated solely to listing resources. For example, many of our blog posts have â€œfurther readingâ€ sections where we list and link to related resources from other websites:Here are the search operators you can use to find these opportunities:Keyword â€œfurther readingâ€Keyword â€œmore resourcesâ€Keyword â€œother resourcesâ€Keyword â€œfavorite resourcesâ€Keyword â€œfavorite toolsâ€Then itâ€™s just a case of opening each search result, using CTRL/CMD+F to search for the footprint on the page, and checking that they link to external resources in the section (not just internal resources).If the opportunity looks promising, find the site ownerâ€™s email address and pitch your resource.Here are the pros and cons of pitching these types of pages:ProsConsFewer people are doing it (less competitive).Not as many of these pages around.Links are often higher quality than â€œtraditionalâ€ resource pages.Their creators arenâ€™t looking for suggestions or feedback, which may mean lower conversion rate.If you can build a relationship with the site owner or at least help in some way before pitching, you can overcome some of the cons above.Final thoughts Resource page link building is about as straightforward as it gets. Thatâ€™s probably why so many SEO professionals continue to use this tacticâ€”even in a world of skyscrapers and shotguns. Want a quick recap of everything we covered?
